bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul H. Streit, November 19, 1952

div1.p: Hench makes clear that the Camp Lazear dedication is a significant affair because it is the first time the Cubans have honored Reed. He informs Streit that the Mayo Foundation is placing a wreath beneath the medallion of Finlay and suggests that the Surgeon General might like to do the same.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul H. Streit, November 19, 1952
div1.opener:
November 19, 1952
Major General Paul H. Streit
Commanding General
Walter Reed Army Hospital
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Streit:
div1.p:
It occurred to me that we few Americans who will officially attend the
little dedication ceremony on December 3 at Camp Lazear, should not go
empty-handed. Please see the enclosed letter which I am sending to the
deans of the six or eight medical schools concerned.

Although the affair will be a very modest one (a relatively small group
of people I suspect, standing in the open in the modest surroundings of
Camp Lazear), nevertheless the significance of the occasion is considerable
for reasons which you know. This is the first time that the Cuban Govern-
ment has ever recognized Reed in any way and even though they are of course
and most properly, honoring Finlay, they are honoring Reed and all of his
American colleagues and volunteers.

The Mayo Foundation wishes to express its appreciation of this Cuban at-
titude and has authorized me to request permission from our Cuban hosts to
place a wreath beneath the medallion of Doctor Finlay at the appropriate
time, either before or during the ceremony. It occurred to me that the
Surgeon General might very much wish you to do likewise and have you place
perhaps two wreaths, one in honor of Doctor Finlay and one beneath the
medallion of Major Reed. It would be particularly appropriate if the U. S.
Army could, in this simple way, honor Doctor Finlay for reasons with which
you are also familiar. Better yet, you might decide to place one
wreath on his grave, but I leave that for you to consider and discuss with
your colleagues. I think that if you chose to place an additional wreath
on Finlay's grave, a representative of the Cuban Government and of the
American Embassy (and I would be glad to also) would be glad to accompany
you so that the thing is done properly and in order to enhance the feeling
of good will, a photograph could be taken which could be published perhaps
in Cuban papers, certainly in the Armed Forces Medical Journal.

The Walter Reed Memorial Association might wish to do something similar or
on the other hand, might wish to send merely a telegraphic message. Please
see the enclosed letter. Permit me to send you herewith a photograph of
the blue print of the present plans for the little camp.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
